text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The candidate answer explicitly addresses the concept of goods at risk and explains that it includes goods intended to be 'processed' in NI to become parts of products subsequently imported to the EU. This is covered in Section 5.4, where it discusses the burden of proof and the two-lane system, implying that goods staying in NI or being re-exported to the EU (which includes processing) are treated differently from those going to GB. Specifically, Section 5.3 states: 'The green lane... Goods intended to stay in NI (or to be re-exported to the EU)'. Furthermore, Section 2 states NI must adhere to EU product rules, which inherently covers processing standards for goods staying in NI but destined for the EU market. The explanation of the two-lane system (Green vs Red) directly relates to the final destination, which includes onward movement into the EU market after processing in NI.", "criterion_id": "fc71b680-fd6e-4d06-9a32-d540462c9927"}
